Dr. Donald R. Howard, professor of English, has been officially appointed to the Caroline
Donovan Chair in English, President Muller announced yesterday.
Howard, who succeeds the late
Earl R. Wasserman, has been the

of the University of California

California, he had been a member

Donovan, a wealthy Baltimorean,
bequeathed in her will the sum of

Hopkins on the advice of her
lawyer, who at the time was the
Mayor of Baltimore.

To the Editor:
I would like to voice support for
the Psychology Department's
(abandoned) plan of requiring undergraduate majors to participate
in psychological experiments. I
completed the requirements for a
psych major at JHU last semester,
but took a number of undergraduate psych courses at two other institutions, both of which required
participation in experiments as a
course requirement regardless of
the students' academic major. The
majority of students, myself included, agreed that although participation was at time inconvenient, we had learned first hand
about the stucture of an experiment, the tediousness often involved for the experimenter, problems
encountered, etc. Often times we
actually had fun, many times we
were amazed, and most of the time
we were grateful to hear about experiments with human, rather than
animal, subjects! We were exposed
to the environment which eventually constituted the basis of the
theories we heard in class.
Perhaps a sincere student could
view mandatory participation as an
opportunity to further his education, to experience an aspect of the
field outside the classroom, rather
than as another requirement to be
circumvented. Be a subject four
times in four years—it doesn't
hurt! Query the experimenter as to
hypotheses, procedures, etc.; if he
can't give you information until
the experiment is complete, leave
your box or phone number and ask
that you be informed of the results—you may learn something
very interesting. Don't feel coerced, feel lucky to have the
chance to get involved! At the very
least, consider that you may be
helping a fellow "pursuer of
knowledge" who may otherwise
have to resort to the telephone and
student directory to beg subjects
for his experiments. Someday you
may be in the same position.
Wendy G. Brunhouse

By JOE RODRIGUE
I awakened just before we reached the
bus terminal in Washington. It was five-thirty. The window afforded me a limited
view, and I occupied myself by appraising
the narrow alleys. Upon our arrival, everyone arose to stretch and to collect their
belongings, and got off.
I made the acquaintance of two Marines, and inquired of them the most convenient way of getting to the Cellar Door,
a nightclub in Georgetown. One of them
didn't seem very interested. He was a big
dumb-looking guy, and he tried his best
to ignore me. In fact, we had been sitting
for the past hour without saying a word,
or in his case, I might say, a grunt. The
other gentleman was considerably more
intelligent, however, and was very friendly. "You don't want to go wandering
around here," lie cautioned. "There are a
lot of fairies out, and worse, so watch it."
Once inside the terminal building, he pointed me in the direction of the Information Booth. "Now you just ask that woman how to get to Georgetown. We'll be
right back. Don't move from that spot
until we come back."
I made my.way through the crowd to
the booth. I greeted the woman and
explained my situation. "I've just arrived
from Baltimore on the 4:45. I'm trying to
get to this nightclub in Georgetown, the
Cellar Door, before eight o'clock. What
do you think I should do?" The woman's
glance was skeptical. "I think you should
get on that bus and go right back to
Baltimore,"she replied.
Presently my friends returned. We
stood for a moment, and the two Marines
conversed softly with each other. At once
there appeared beside me a fat, old, white-haired man, who began talking to me.
He seemed interested in my pen, and questioned me about it. He seemed very friendly—too friendly, in. fact; my friends
took me aside. The smart one shook his
head. "See what I told you? He's one of
the fairies." I was a little disconcerted.
When I turned to find him, he had already stumbled away, looking a little chagrined.
I decided to take a cab, and so we
moved outside. After an hour of waiting,
I noticed a cab some distance off driven
by a young black girl. She seemed to be
waving to me. I instinctively turned to
my friends but they had disappeared; I
looked about for a moment but could see
no sign of them. Crossing the street, I
made my way in an awkwardly cautious
fashion to the cab. Yes, she would take
me to the Cellar Door, for a mere dollar
and a quarter. She was very friendly and
quite attractive. I thanked her and got in.
We talked for awhile and she apparently found my behavior to be rather amusing. To her I sounded like a hick, which
of course was an accurate- appraisal. She
restored in me some degree of confidence
and upon our arrival at the Cellar Door, I
thanked her warmly and gave her three
dollars, which was regrettably the most I
could afford.

window, easily overlooked from the
street. This outward appearance might

Eastern Avenue and South Broadway,
this once diapidated edifice remains
today. On the inside it looks like there
was once a fire and flood at the same
time. There are huge portholes of green
light and decorated serpents on the wall
panels, whose color ranges from the pink
of a tongue burnt by funky smoking to
the purple of a liver done in by booze.

our society as a monument of an era
more twisted than our own, and so it is
preserved to remind culture of the competition for The Most Wanton Epoch of

To the Editor:
I would like to voice support for
the Psychology Department's
(abandoned) plan of requiring undergraduate majors to participate
in psychological experiments. I
completed the requirements for a
psych major at JHU last semester,
but took a number of undergraduate psych courses at two other institutions, both of which required
participation in experiments as a
course requirement regardless of
the students' academic major. The
majority of students, myself included, agreed that although participation was at time inconvenient, we had learned first hand
about the stucture of an experiment, the tediousness often involved for the experimenter, problems
encountered, etc. Often times we
actually had fun, many times we
were amazed, and most of the time
we were grateful to hear about experiments with human, rather than
animal, subjects! We were exposed
to the environment which eventually constituted the basis of the
theories we heard in class.
Perhaps a sincere student could
view mandatory participation as an
opportunity to further his education, to experience an aspect of the
field outside the classroom, rather
than as another requirement to be
circumvented. Be a subject four
times in four years—it doesn't
hurt! Query the experimenter as to
hypotheses, procedures, etc.; if he
can't give you information until
the experiment is complete, leave
your box or phone number and ask
that you be informed of the results—you may learn something
very interesting. Don't feel coerced, feel lucky to have the
chance to get involved! At the very
least, consider that you may be
helping a fellow "pursuer of
knowledge" who may otherwise
have to resort to the telephone and
student directory to beg subjects
for his experiments. Someday you
may be in the same position.
Wendy G. Brunhouse
